questions.text: A 72-year-old man with Parkinson’s disease presents for a routine follow-up. He reports improvement in his tremor and bradykinesia but is concerned about a recent development of a net-like purplish discoloration on his lower legs, which worsens in cold weather. He denies pain or itching. His medications include carbidopa-levodopa, pramipexole, and a recently added agent for dyskinesia control. Which of the following medications is MOST likely responsible for his skin changes?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • A. Amantadine – Correct • Used in Parkinson’s disease for treatment of levodopa-induced dyskinesias. • Mechanism: NMDA receptor antagonist with dopaminergic effects. • Side Effect: Livedo reticularis is a unique and characteristic adverse effect. • Usually reversible upon discontinuation of the drug.
  • • B. Levodopa • Mainstay treatment for Parkinson’s disease. • May cause motor fluctuations and dyskinesia, but does not cause livedo reticularis. • Skin reactions are rare.
  • • C. Pramipexole • Dopamine agonist. • Can cause sleep attacks, impulse control disorders, and hypotension, but not associated with skin discoloration.
  • • D. Selegiline • MAO-B inhibitor used as adjunct therapy. • May cause insomnia, nausea, and serotonin syndrome if combined improperly. • No association with livedo reticularis.

questions.text: Find out false statement

options.label: A
options.text: Azithromycin associated with tendon rupture, particularly in older adults

options.label: B
options.text: Ciprofloxacin inhibits DNA gyrase and topoisomerase IV

options.label: C
options.text: Imipenem is resistant to beta-lactamase degradation

questions.correct_answer: A. Azithromycin associated with tendon rupture, particularly in older adults
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • A. Azithromycin is associated with tendon rupture — FALSE • Azithromycin is a macrolide antibiotic, mainly associated with: o QT prolongation o GI upset • It does NOT cause tendon rupture. • Tendon rupture is a known side effect of fluoroquinolones (like ciprofloxacin), especially in older adults and those on corticosteroids.
  • • B. Ciprofloxacin inhibits DNA gyrase and topoisomerase IV — TRUE • Ciprofloxacin, a fluoroquinolone, targets: o DNA gyrase in Gram-negative bacteria o Topoisomerase IV in Gram-positive bacteria • This disrupts bacterial DNA replication and transcription — bactericidal effect
  • • C. Imipenem is resistant to beta-lactamase degradation — TRUE • Imipenem is a carbapenem antibiotic. • It is broad-spectrum and resistant to most β-lactamases (except metallo-β-lactamases). • Often used with cilastatin to inhibit renal degradation.
  • • D. Linezolid is bacteriostatic — TRUE • Linezolid is an oxazolidinone antibiotic. • Inhibits the initiation of bacterial protein synthesis (binds 50S subunit). • Bacteriostatic against most organisms (except bactericidal for streptococci). • Used for MRSA, VRE, and drug-resistant Gram-positives

questions.text: Which of the following anti-helminthic drugs causes neuromuscular blockade leading to worm spastic paralysis?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Why the Other Options Are Incorrect:
  • • A. Albendazole • Mechanism: Inhibits microtubule polymerization by binding β-tubulin. • Disrupts cellular transport and glucose uptake → energy depletion → death. • Used for broad-spectrum helminthic infections (e.g., neurocysticercosis, echinococcus). • No neuromuscular action.
  • • B. Ivermectin • Mechanism: Binds to glutamate-gated chloride channels, leading to paralysis by hyperpolarization of nerve and muscle cells. • Used for strongyloidiasis and onchocerciasis (river blindness). • Though it leads to paralysis, it’s not via nicotinic blockade and thus different from pyrantel’s neuromuscular blockade.
  • • C. Praziquantel • Mechanism: Increases membrane permeability to calcium, causing tetanic contraction and paralysis of flukes and tapeworms. • Used mainly for schistosomiasis and cestode (tapeworm) infections. • Acts via calcium influx, not neuromuscular blockade.

questions.text: A patient with schizophrenia presents to the ED with high fever, lead-pipe rigidity, and elevated CK levels. Which drug is most likely responsible?

A 62-year-old woman with a history of diabetes presents with a painful, vesicular rash distributed along the right thoracic dermatome. Which of the following is the most appropriate antiviral therapy?

A 45-year-old man on an antidepressant for major depression presents with myoclonus, hyperreflexia, and agitation. He was recently started on linezolid for an infection. What drug useful for treating these symptoms?

Find out the true statements A. Phenobarbital is the first-line drug for treating seizures in neonates B. lacosamide enhances fast inactivation of voltage-gated sodium channels C. Ethosuximide is prescribed an antiepileptic for absence seizures with myoclonic jerk D. Cannabidiol useful in Dravet syndrome E. Oxcarbazepine has less risk of SIADH than carbamazepine
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Phenobarbital is widely accepted as the first-line treatment for neonatal seizures. It enhances GABA-A receptor activity, leading to neuronal inhibition. Despite sedative effects, it is effective in immature brains where GABA can still have depolarizing effects.
  • • Lacosamide enhances slow inactivation of voltage-gated sodium channels, not fast inactivation.
  • • Ethosuximide is first-line for pure absence seizures, but not for myoclonic jerks.
  • • In absence with myoclonus (e.g., juvenile myoclonic epilepsy), valproic acid is preferred.
  • • Cannabidiol (CBD) is approved for Dravet syndrome, a rare and severe form of childhood epilepsy. It reduces seizure frequency and is used as adjunctive therapy. Cannabidiol also approved for Lennox-Gastaut Syndrome and Tuberous Sclerosis Complex (TSC).
  • • Oxcarbazepine is actually more associated with hyponatremia and SIADH than carbamazepine, especially in elderly patients. Monitoring sodium is essential.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most appropriate antidote for cyanide poisoning?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Antidote: Hydroxocobalamin • Mechanism: Binds cyanide to form cyanocobalamin (vitamin B12), which is excreted in the urine. • Advantages: o Acts rapidly o Does not lower blood pressure (unlike nitrites) o Preferred in smoke inhalation victims, where coexisting carbon monoxide poisoning is a risk Key Point: Hydroxocobalamin is the first-line treatment for cyanide poisoning, especially in emergency and prehospital settings.
  • • Why the Other Options Are Incorrect:
  • • A. N-acetylcysteine (NAC) • Used for: Acetaminophen (paracetamol) toxicity • Mechanism: Replenishes glutathione stores to detoxify NAPQI • No role in cyanide poisoning
  • • C. Flumazenil • Used for: Benzodiazepine overdose • Mechanism: GABA-A receptor antagonist • Dangerous if mixed drug ingestion (can cause seizures) • Not relevant to cyanide toxicity
  • • D. Amyl nitrite • Was part of an older cyanide antidote kit • Mechanism: Induces methemoglobinemia, which binds cyanide, forming cyanmethemoglobin • However, this reduces oxygen-carrying capacity and can worsen hypoxia, especially in smoke inhalation victims • No longer first-line; used only when hydroxocobalamin is unavailable

questions.text: Which of the following reactions is a Phase I metabolic transformation that typically introduces a polar functional group?
Which monoclonal antibody binds VEGF-A, inhibiting angiogenesis in metastatic cancers?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • A. Trastuzumab • Target: HER2/neu receptor (ERBB2) • Use: HER2-positive breast cancer and gastric cancer • Mechanism: Inhibits proliferation of HER2-overexpressing cells • Does NOT bind VEGF-A
  • • C. Cetuximab • Target: Epidermal Growth Factor Receptor (EGFR) • Use: Colorectal cancer (KRAS wild-type), head and neck squamous cell carcinoma • Mechanism: Blocks EGFR signaling, inhibiting cell proliferation • Does NOT inhibit angiogenesis via VEGF-A
  • • D. Rituximab • Target: CD20 antigen on B cells • Use: o Non-Hodgkin lymphoma o Chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) o Rheumatoid arthritis o ANCA-associated vasculitis • Mechanism: B-cell depletion • Unrelated to VEGF or angiogenesis

questions.text: Which agent causes maximum risk of hand-foot syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • A. Capecitabine – Correct • Class: Oral prodrug of 5-Fluorouracil (5-FU) • Mechanism: Converted to 5-FU in the body, inhibiting thymidylate synthase → DNA synthesis inhibition • Unique Feature: o Has high and prolonged exposure in skin tissues, especially hands and feet. o Causes dose-limiting and more frequent hand-foot syndrome compared to IV 5-FU. • Clinical Use: Breast cancer, colorectal cancer, gastric cancer • Management: o Dose reduction or interruption o Emollients, urea cream, cooling, and sometimes pyridoxine (though evidence is limited)
  • • B. 5-Fluorouracil (5-FU) • Also causes hand-foot syndrome but less frequently and less severely than capecitabine. • IV 5-FU is less concentrated in peripheral tissues, leading to lower risk.
  • • C. Methotrexate • Folate antagonist; used in cancer, autoimmune diseases, and ectopic pregnancy • Common toxicities: mucositis, hepatotoxicity, myelosuppression • Not typically associated with hand-foot syndrome
  • • D. Cytarabine • Antimetabolite used mainly in acute leukemias • Common toxicities: cerebellar toxicity, myelosuppression, chemical conjunctivitis • Hand-foot syndrome is rare with this drug

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is approved for use in chronic Immune Thrombocytopenia (ITP) refractory to first-line therapies?
Which agent is used in rheumatoid arthritis and acts by inhibiting dihydroorotate dehydrogenase, blocking pyrimidine synthesis?
Which of the following drugs targets the α4β7 integrin and is useful in the treatment of Crohn’s disease?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • A. Aprepitant – Incorrect • Class: Neurokinin-1 (NK1) receptor antagonist • Use: Primarily used to prevent chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting. • Not involved in the treatment of inflammatory bowel disease.
  • • C. Natalizumab – Incorrect • Mechanism: Targets α4-integrin, but not selectively for α4β7. • Use: Approved for multiple sclerosis and Crohn’s disease, but associated with progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML) due to JC virus reactivation. • Less gut-specific than Vedolizumab, and therefore has more systemic immunosuppressive risks.
  • • D. Ustekinumab – Incorrect • Mechanism: Monoclonal antibody against interleukin-12 and interleukin-23. • Use: Approved for Crohn’s disease, ulcerative colitis, psoriasis, and psoriatic arthritis. • While it is effective for Crohn’s disease, it does not target α4β7 integrin.

questions.text: What is the primary target of inclisiran, a novel lipid-lowering agent?
A patient with HFrEF on full-dose ARNI therapy continues to have high resting HR. Which drug reduces HR without affecting contractility or BP?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • B. Ivabradine – Correct Answer • Mechanism: Selective inhibitor of the funny current (If) in the sinoatrial node. • Effect: Slows heart rate without affecting: o Myocardial contractility o Blood pressure • Indication: o Symptomatic HFrEF (EF ≤35%) o Sinus rhythm o Resting heart rate ≥70 bpm o Despite maximally tolerated beta-blocker or if beta-blockers are contraindicated • Unique Feature: Does not depress myocardial function or lower systemic BP, making it especially useful in patients with low BP or borderline EF.
  • • A. Bisoprolol – Incorrect • Beta-1 selective blocker, part of guideline-directed therapy for HFrEF. • Reduces HR and BP, and negatively affects contractility initially. • May not be tolerated in patients with already low blood pressure or severe HF symptoms.
  • • C. Verapamil – Incorrect • Non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker • Reduces HR, BP, and negatively inotropic (decreases contractility). • Contraindicated in HFrEF due to risk of worsening heart failure.
  • • D. Amiodarone – Incorrect • Primarily an antiarrhythmic; does have rate-slowing effects. • Has complex effects: blocks sodium, potassium, and calcium channels and beta-adrenergic receptors. • Not a first-line rate control agent in HFrEF for sinus tachycardia. • Significant toxicity (pulmonary, hepatic, thyroid) with chronic use.

questions.text: Which of the following DIURETIC is used in pseudotumor cerebri (idiopathic intracranial hypertension)?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • A. Acetazolamide – Correct • Class: Carbonic anhydrase inhibitor • Mechanism: o Inhibits carbonic anhydrase in the choroid plexus, reducing cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) production o Also acts in the proximal tubule of the nephron • Effect: Lowers intracranial pressure by decreasing CSF volume • First-line treatment for pseudotumor cerebri
  • • Why the Other Options Are Incorrect:
  • • B. Amiloride • Potassium-sparing diuretic; blocks ENaC in the collecting duct • No effect on CSF production or ICP • Not used in pseudotumor cerebri
  • • C. Mannitol • Osmotic diuretic • Used in acute management of intracranial hypertension (e.g., head trauma), but not suitable for chronic idiopathic intracranial hypertension • Works by drawing fluid out of brain parenchyma, but not used long-term
  • • D. Furosemide • Loop diuretic; inhibits Na⁺/K⁺/2Cl⁻ cotransporter in the loop of Henle • Occasionally used adjunctively, but not first-line • Does not significantly reduce CSF production

questions.text: A 56-year-old diabetic patient with NYHA Class III heart failure is started on a new oral anti-diabetic medication. Two weeks later, he presents with weight gain and worsening peripheral edema. Which of the following medications is MOST likely responsible?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • C. Pioglitazone – Correct Answer • Class: Thiazolidinedione (TZD) • Mechanism: Activates PPAR-γ receptors, increasing insulin sensitivity in adipose tissue, liver, and skeletal muscle. • Adverse Effects: o Fluid retention o Weight gain o Peripheral edema o Can worsen heart failure, particularly NYHA Class III and IV • Contraindication: Avoid in symptomatic heart failure due to risk of volume overload and edema.
  • • A. Dapagliflozin • Class: SGLT2 inhibitor • Mechanism: Promotes renal glucose excretion • Effects: o Weight loss o Reduction in heart failure hospitalizations o Diuretic-like effect (mild natriuresis) • Important: Dapagliflozin is beneficial in patients with HFrEF and reduces fluid overload, not causes it.
  • • B. Glimepiride • Class: Sulfonylurea • Mechanism: Stimulates insulin secretion from pancreatic β-cells • Adverse Effects: o Hypoglycemia o Weight gain • Does not typically cause edema or worsen heart failure.
  • • D. Sitagliptin • Class: DPP-4 inhibitor • Mechanism: Increases endogenous GLP-1 levels → enhances insulin release and decreases glucagon • Generally weight-neutral • Minimal risk of edema • Some agents in this class (e.g., saxagliptin) have been associated with HF risk, but sitagliptin itself is not clearly linked to worsening HF or edema.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man, 3 days post-TURP, reports lower abdominal fullness and inability to void. He is stable, with a distended bladder and post-void residual of 550 mL on ultrasound. Neurologic exam is normal, and catheterization drains clear urine. Which cholinergic agent is most appropriate to stimulate bladder emptying?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Why Bethanechol? • Mechanism: Direct muscarinic receptor agonist (primarily M3) → activates bladder smooth muscle. • Use: Indicated for non-obstructive urinary retention and neurogenic bladder. • Promotes bladder contraction and facilitates micturition.
  • • Why the Other Options Are Wrong: • B. Physostigmine: o Indirect cholinergic agonist (reversible AChE inhibitor), crosses BBB → mostly CNS effects. o Used to reverse anticholinergic toxicity, not to stimulate bladder directly. • C. Carbachol: o Potent cholinergic agonist with both muscarinic and nicotinic activity, mostly used topically in glaucoma. o Not suitable systemically due to risk of uncontrolled cholinergic effects. • D. Donepezil: o Centrally acting AChE inhibitor, used in Alzheimer’s disease. o No role in treating bladder dysfunction or stimulating peripheral M3 receptors.
